trial_identification.studytitle: Reducing fatigue after brain injury: a pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of education versus activity coaching on fatigue in adults post-traumatic brain injury (TBI) when compared to usual care: a pilot study

conditions.healthcondition: Mild or moderate traumatic brain injury

interventions.interventions:
Arm 1 CBT based fatigue management education, one hour group based session held weekly for 6 weeks.
Arm 2 Activity coaching (an approach using techniques, such as motivational interviewing, problem identification, solution generation and goal setting, to increase motivation and identify activities that are meaningful and sustainable for the participant) one hour group based session held weekly for 6 weeks
Arm 3 Usual care
interventions.comparator: Treatment as usual - this is defined as receipt of medical and psychological treatment as provided by the service as part of standard care.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Fatigue as measured by fatigue severity scale
Fatigue as measured by the Checklist of Individual Strength

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Health related quality of life as assessed by the RAND Short form-36
Memory as assessed by the Cognitive failures questionnaire
Mood as assessed by the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale
Illness perceptions as assessed by the Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire
Level of Physical Activity as assessed by the Physical Activity and Disability Survey - Revised

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 3-12 months post- (mild or moderate) TBI Experiencing moderate to severe fatigue as defined as a Fatigue Severity Scale score >3

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be recruited via concussion clinics in the Auckland region of New Zealand (NZ). After confirming eligibility to participate in the study, participants will be randomised to one of the three treatment groups (CBT based fatigue management, activity coaching or usual care). Participants will be randomised centrally by computer

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Fatigue is a common and persistent problem after brain injury. This study aims to look at whether group sessions focusing on increasing physical activity or fatigue management education can reduce levels of fatigue for people who have experienced a brain injury, in comparison to those receiving treatment as usual
